instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short or no?
threads.message:
Hi,

I've a liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.
The liquid damage was around SMC and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.

I had to change the SMC, because there was no green light.
After I replaced the SMC this macbook was working fine.
However after few hours it turned off and the green light went off.

There was a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> (40 ohm short).
I hooked up my PSU give it 1V and 1A. It drew 0.8A and nicely went down to 0A in 10sec or less.
So of course I couldn't find the shorted component. It's not like something blown.... the short just was gone.

Well, after an hour the problem is back. The macbook turns off and on. It starts booting and turns off and on.
Sometimes as soon as the white screen comes on sometimes after it booted. It does the some thing on my desk without anything attached.
I tried different DC-IN board.

I have a low resistance on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>. It's now 400 Ohm. What could this be? I guess it's a leaking cap just the question is how the hell I'm gonna find it?

Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short or no?
threads.message: Under that foam thingie near the audio circuit are two caps that always die,I think <CAPACITOR>C6403</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C6405</CAPACITOR>. Remove them. You can't see them smoke when you run voltage through them because they're hiding under the foam.
